quote_a: I know it could save me time, but again, for the reasons I mentioned, I prefer not to do it.
quote_b: I always have a solution. I haven't had a situation where I needed it excessively. I always manage to do as before and find an alternative solution to meet my needs.
explanation: In one breath the participant acknowledges AI would save them time, and in another claims they have never had a situation where they needed it excessively — these sentiments sit in mild tension.

quote_a: I always have a solution. I haven't had a situation where I needed it excessively. I always manage to do as before and find an alternative solution to meet my needs.
explanation: The repeated insistence on always managing without AI and never needing it reads as performative self-sufficiency — convincing themselves rather than simply describing their behaviour.

quote_a: 3 - Moderate trust
quote_b: the most amazing AI personal assistant would be in my inbox helping me to filter information. It would distinguish between what I really need to know and what is nice to know, identifying jobs to be done, key dates, and anything related to financials all in one place, including the last possible date I need to pay something.
explanation: The participant explicitly rates their trust in AI as only moderate (3), yet describes an expansive vision of AI with deep access to their inbox, finances, and personal scheduling — a level of integration that implies far greater trust than stated.

quote_a: I felt okay about being interviewed by a person that's not a human, but I also know who the study is being run by, which probably isn't a true reflection of how I would feel if I were receiving this from nobody. Even if it's coming from AI, I know that there is always a person behind the study.
quote_b: Perhaps a small video introduction from that person first or some kind of human interaction would be good.
explanation: The participant says they felt okay with AI interviewing, then qualifies that comfort by requiring visible human framing and interaction, weakening the initial confidence.

quote_a: Perhaps the task is too complex for AI to create from scratch, and I probably should have set the context more clearly.
explanation: After failing to build an AI agent with Retool, the participant immediately deflects blame from AI onto themselves and task complexity, offering unprompted justification rather than a neutral description of what happened.

quote_a: These days, there are certain competitions or projects that come my way where I’m instructed not to use AI. Even though I still use it for inspiration and reference, I will not use it directly.
quote_b: Apparently, any and all. But what can you do?
explanation: The participant acknowledges the restriction covers any and all AI use, yet in the same breath reveals they continue using it for inspiration and reference, dismissing the rule with a shrug rather than complying with it.

quote_a: Apparently, any and all. But what can you do?
explanation: The casual dismissal of a rule they are actively breaking reads as unprompted self-justification rather than genuine description of a constraint.

quote_a: I very often ask AI about interesting facts about the world or various issues for which I do not yet know the answers. AI explains all issues very well and in detail, also talks about various things, so it is a very interesting tool for everyday use, of course with caution.
quote_b: I hope it doesn't go in the wrong direction, that someday robots will rule us, but at the moment I think it's a cool, useful, and helpful tool if you don't use it all the time.
explanation: The participant recommends AI for everyday use but immediately qualifies this with caution, and later pulls back further by stipulating it should not be used all the time, eroding their initial endorsement.

quote_a: Yes, people are false. Face to face they tell you different things, and behind your back they can stab you in the back. Unfortunately, people can't be honest. They can't say straight out what's on their mind. They prefer to gossip rather than just be people.
explanation: The sweeping condemnation of all human honesty reads as unprompted justification for preferring AI as a conversational partner, convincing themselves that AI is superior rather than simply describing a preference.

quote_a: Many people are lonely these days because technology has unfortunately developed in such a way that it's easier for us to write a message than to meet someone face to face, live, for coffee, for a walk, for anything.
quote_b: Yes, people are false. Face to face they tell you different things, and behind your back they can stab you in the back. Unfortunately, people can't be honest. They can't say straight out what's on their mind. They prefer to gossip rather than just be people.
explanation: The participant blames technology for destroying face-to-face human connection, yet in the same interview actively dismisses human interaction as dishonest and untrustworthy, undermining the premise that real-world connection is worth preserving.

quote_a: I think it should go back to how it used to be, when children were in the yard, everyone played together. Now, these days, you don't see children playing football in the yard as often as they used to, jumping rope, just living together as a community, playing together and just living.
quote_b: I had the impression that AI is more willing to talk, more factual and specific. I won't even mention the knowledge, the conversation was smooth. As I say, factual. Everything I wanted to know was always willing to talk, and that's important.
explanation: The participant calls for a return to community and face-to-face interaction, yet their own stated behaviour turns to AI for conversation and connection rather than the human community they say they value.

quote_a: It kind of didn’t read or interpret what I wanted. But again, I don’t see that as an AI problem. AI is not plugged into my brain; I still have to give it something to go on.
quote_b: Perfect personal AI assistant. But probably to take my mom brain and interpret all the things, plug into my brain, see everything gosh. It sounds very scary. But see everything I read, whether it’s on WhatsApp or on school newsletters or hear about or talk about, and almost come up with a to do list or an events calendar.
explanation: She defends AI not being plugged into her brain as a reasonable and accepted limitation, then describes her ideal AI as doing exactly that — plugging into her brain to interpret everything.

quote_a: 3 - Moderate trust
quote_b: I like to use AI to assess some of the images that I upload as a form of DIY. I take pictures of a broken wall or a broken wall socket, anything that I don't know how to manage myself, and then I get AI to analyze it. It tells me how much paint I need to buy and where I can purchase whatever tools I need for the do-it-yourself home project.
explanation: She self-rates her AI trust at only 3 out of 5, yet describes enthusiastic, high-reliance AI use for practical home decisions, suggesting her stated trust level does not reflect her actual dependence on AI outputs.

quote_a: Yeah, I definitely think it affects how open or detailed I am in my responses. I suppose when you deal with humans, there's that human aspect where you almost don't want to let the interviewer down. You sometimes say things that you think the interviewer maybe wants to hear instead of actually expressing what you really think. I think it's a very human approach, a very human thing to try to either impress or make the interviewer happy.
explanation: This unprompted justification of the AI interview format over human interviews reads as the participant convincing themselves (and implicitly the AI interviewer) that the AI format is superior, which is itself a form of social desirability signalling directed at the AI.

quote_a: That in the future it could help in everyday life but not replace face-to-face contact.
explanation: While describing their ideal AI assistant, the participant inserts an unprompted caveat defending human contact, suggesting they are reassuring themselves rather than simply describing a feature preference.

quote_a: Coffee machine, refrigerator that would inform me that something has run out.
quote_b: AI still doesn't fully express itself correctly in a given language, so I preferred to contact a person from this side.
explanation: The participant expresses enthusiasm for deeper AI integration in daily life but reveals a behavioural preference for human contact when given the choice, suggesting the stated openness to AI does not fully match their actual behaviour.

quote_a: Right now, I do not like AI to touch my calendar and emails too much. Well, they are doing that anyway, like Clockwise.
quote_b: I don't want AI to be integrated with any other digital tools that I'm using at the moment because then there's a large chunk of that tied to payment. I'd rather not have expensive mistakes until I know that the AI is as reliable as it could be.
explanation: The participant states they do not want AI touching their calendar or integrating with their tools, but in the same breath acknowledges they are already actively using Clockwise, an AI calendar integration tool.

quote_a: I don't want AI to be integrated with any other digital tools that I'm using at the moment because then there's a large chunk of that tied to payment. I'd rather not have expensive mistakes until I know that the AI is as reliable as it could be.
quote_b: for personal use, I chat a lot with my friends and family ... my chat should sit alongside the other chats that I have, so I can very quickly pull something from the AI and send it to my friends and family or generate something for laughs.
explanation: The participant flatly rejects integrating AI with any existing digital tools, yet in the same question explicitly wants their AI chat integrated into their personal messaging apps alongside other chats.

quote_a: For personal use, it's meeting my needs pretty well.
quote_b: If, rather than having to go to each of those threads ... it could combine all that together and know what's going on in my life. So when I'm asking a question, it could say, for Justin's golf outing, you should do X, Y, Z, and considering what you're going through over here, it might be a good idea to do this.
explanation: The participant claims personal use needs are met pretty well, then describes a substantial unmet need for cross-context understanding that reveals the earlier satisfaction statement was overstated.

quote_a: if I was using AI, for example, planning this golfing and whatnot, this is logged in through my personal Gmail account, sending dates to my calendar or automating sending out emails to people that have registered, things like that.
quote_b: I don't mind doing all those extra tasks on my own because then I can really make sure they're done right.
explanation: The participant expresses enthusiasm for AI automating calendar and email tasks, then immediately states a preference for doing those same tasks manually to ensure quality.

quote_a: Not so much couldn't, I'm probably more under the realm of shouldn't. I'm thinking about some privacy concerns. What is it that I want to put into, you know, do I particularly want to train somebody else's model, and what happens to that data after the fact? So, again, I haven't encountered something that I wasn't able to do, more that I chose not to do.
quote_b: can I ask you to send an email at some point in the future? Or, you know, other things that aren't synchronous but are asynchronous activities?
explanation: Participant expresses strong privacy concern about what they put into AI and what happens to that data, yet simultaneously desires AI to autonomously send emails and act on their behalf — tasks that require trusting AI with more sensitive access and agency than a simple query.

quote_a: I was impressed with the follow-up questions. It really seemed like it was able to understand my responses and then have a pretty good follow-up question to those responses.
quote_b: I think it could ultimately be soul-sucking in the long term as it becomes more and more prevalent.
explanation: The participant expresses genuine admiration for the AI interview experience yet simultaneously describes AI interaction as soul-sucking, revealing opposing sentiments on the same topic of AI-mediated conversation.

quote_a: I use AI for search pretty much daily, looking up different questions around recipes or really anything that comes up that I'm curious about, like random facts, health-related topics, ingredients, and food.
quote_b: if I have a very specific question, like, "Is rice healthier when it's refrigerated?" I might get mixed answers or it will show different articles that have different opinions. Sometimes, it doesn't always make the answer clear, and it can even provide a wrong answer citing an incorrect source.
explanation: The participant commits to daily AI search as their primary lookup tool but then reveals the tool frequently gives mixed, unclear, or outright wrong answers — a gap between stated reliance and described reliability.

quote_a: It's actually become a fairly nice companion. I'm quite happy to do what Tyler Cohen suggests, which is to put a lot of myself out there so that the AIs can engage with me.
quote_b: ultimately, this is not a real relationship; it's more like a mirror.
explanation: He describes AI as a companion he is happy to share himself with, then directly contradicts this by saying it is not a real relationship and merely a mirror.

quote_a: In some ways, I feel like I live on, way beyond this physical existence, so there's a bit of vanity in that as well.
explanation: The unprompted acknowledgement of vanity reads as self-justification, softening a narcissistic motivation rather than straightforwardly describing it.

quote_a: I'm using a shared account that is paid for by my company. I'm currently undergoing cancer and chemo treatment. What I would like to do is upload all the past ten years' worth of doctor and medical reports and ask it to make sense of it.
quote_b: It's actually become a fairly nice companion. I'm quite happy to do what Tyler Cohen suggests, which is to put a lot of myself out there so that the AIs can engage with me.
explanation: He stops sharing sensitive personal data with AI due to privacy concerns, yet elsewhere states he is quite happy to put a lot of himself out there for AI engagement.

quote_a: In my personal life, this would be more logo or tattoo ideas that I have, or just different graphics and work. It could be related to PowerPoint or creating slideshows and decks.
quote_b: I was trying to create an idea for a tattoo that I wanted to get, and I kept asking it to change the style of the image to replicate another style more. I even included reference images, but it just wasn't able to recreate it in the way I was hoping.
explanation: She describes using AI regularly for logo and tattoo ideas, yet recounts a clear failure at exactly that task where AI could not meet her needs despite multiple attempts with reference images.

quote_a: I don't think the experience is much different than a survey necessarily. I personally prefer not to do video or oral interviews. A written survey would be more preferable to me, I think.
quote_b: I'm looking for a hands-off dictation type situation where I can think aloud. I want to be able to say, "Oh, create this list," and then I can tell everything I want on the list, and it can formulate it itself. Or, "I want to make this grocery list. Can you organize it by category?" or "Add this to my calendar. Remind me of this thing that's coming up," that kind of stuff.
explanation: She explicitly prefers written communication over oral interaction, yet her ideal AI experience centres on speaking aloud and hands-off voice dictation.

quote_a: I wanted to ask AI to be a host for the business, but I believe you need to have a human touch sometimes for that. There are too many different things and too many different people and personalities on this earth for me to trust it fully with AI right now.
quote_b: In the specific business tasks, I want it to handle the hosting portion of the business day in and day out, making sure I have cleaning schedules that are there every single time. If someone is not able to come and clean, I want it to be able to choose someone from the different apps that are out there, someone who is trustworthy and has great attendance records, to do that on its own for me, without me having to ask it.
explanation: The participant explicitly says they cannot trust AI to be a host due to the need for human nuance, yet immediately describes their ideal AI as fully autonomous host manager operating "day in and day out" without being asked.

quote_a: It's actually nice to know that the AI is listening and is able to provide follow-up questions based on my previous responses. That was really refreshing. We don't always get that from a human interviewer, so that was nice.
quote_b: I think a human would probably have follow-up questions in mind, but with this AI interviewer, it feels a little bit more spontaneous.
explanation: In the first quote the participant says AI is better than humans at providing follow-up questions; in the second, they say humans are more deliberate with follow-up while the AI feels spontaneous — two opposing framings of who is stronger at planned follow-up.

quote_a: It seems they didn't have enough information, which was okay with me. So, yeah, I wasn't able to get the response I was looking for from the AI assistants because they just didn't have enough information on me.
explanation: The participant dismisses a clear failure to get useful AI responses with "which was okay with me", yet immediately after spends considerable time describing an aspirational AI deeply integrated into their personal data — suggesting the limitation was not genuinely okay.

quote_a: In my personal life, I would say that keeping my emails more organized would be a huge help, and this would also benefit my professional life.
quote_b: I really haven't looked into any because I don't seem to find the time to pay attention to my own personal email.
explanation: The participant frames email organisation as a hugely important priority yet admits they have not looked into any tools to address it, revealing a gap between stated importance and actual behaviour.

quote_a: I do like it better than having to type it out because I think you get a much faster response, and you can't really delete or take back what you just said.
explanation: The participant reframes an inherent limitation of spoken input (inability to delete or retract words) as a positive quality, suggesting a rationalisation of their preference rather than a straightforward description.

quote_a: I would be interested in continuing to use it for work, but I also have concerns that it might replace me.
quote_b: I am a little old school and a bit nervous about using AI exclusively. I always like to double-check that it's accurate, both in work and outside of work.
explanation: She expresses genuine interest in using AI for work, then immediately undercuts it with nervousness about exclusive AI use and a need to always double-check, walking back the positive intent.

quote_a: It can't drive a car, it can't take care of my child, and it can't buy groceries for me. So I think right now, I'm just enjoying its current capabilities.
explanation: She deflects from her limited AI engagement by listing physical-world limitations that are irrelevant to her actual digital use cases, convincing herself that satisfaction with minimal use is justified.

quote_a: I know that all AI is ultimately just a bullshitting machine with the highest probability of matching what the requester has hoped for.
explanation: After spending the interview describing numerous AI tools they use and many more they want, the participant closes with an unprompted cynical framing of AI as a bullshitting machine — a defensive deflation that reads as rationalising their extensive reliance on a technology they are ambivalent about.

quote_a: The authenticity of the human connection and the human experience is obviously lacking in this.
quote_b: The deeper and more specific you can get, the more likely you can flourish and expand upon the notions of authenticity within the framework of that personality type that you chose.
explanation: The participant flatly states that human authenticity is obviously lacking in AI, but then describes a strategy by which AI can achieve authenticity — contradicting the premise that authenticity is absent.

quote_a: I think finance is probably one of the best cases and uses for AI.
quote_b: I know that all AI is ultimately just a bullshitting machine with the highest probability of matching what the requester has hoped for.
explanation: The participant enthusiastically endorses AI as one of the best tools for finance, but elsewhere dismisses all AI as fundamentally a bullshitting machine — a directly opposing valuation of AI capability.

quote_a: when I needed new tires for my car after getting quotes, I found GPT to be really useful. It helped me by summarizing the options I had, which gave me confidence in the choices I was making.
quote_b: I have had a couple of instances where I recall it doing things that I knew were not correct, and I had to prompt it to check things.
explanation: The participant claims AI gave them confident, reliable decision support but also admits it produced errors they had to catch, undermining the reliability implied by expressed confidence.

quote_a: when I needed new tires for my car after getting quotes, I found GPT to be really useful. It helped me by summarizing the options I had, which gave me confidence in the choices I was making.
quote_b: 3 - Moderate trust
explanation: The participant reports high confidence in AI-assisted purchase decisions yet simultaneously rates their overall trust in AI at only moderate (3/5), revealing a gap between enacted reliance and stated trust.

quote_a: I was expecting something more like ChatGPT when you are asking questions via voice, where it would actually come back and talk to me.
quote_b: I think it probably would have made me feel put on the spot a bit more. But, yeah, hearing it could be kind of a little bit odd, but it was just sort of what I was expecting.
explanation: The participant first frames voice interaction as what they expected and wanted, then immediately hedges by saying it would have felt odd and put them on the spot, walking back the expressed preference.

quote_a: But I also try to have it generate a weekly meal plan for me, just to help take off some of the mental load of having to think about dinner all the time. I must say that it didn't really help me much.
quote_b: if my personal assistant could make sure that I have food in the home every night with a healthy, easy-to-cook meal, that would be great. I don't want to have to think about it or fall back on maybe ordering a pizza every week. I just want the assistant to decide for me so I can eat something healthy without the effort.
explanation: She reports that AI meal planning did not help her, yet her ideal assistant is still built around the same meal-decision automation that has already failed her.

quote_a: I would need to feed it so much information, like my calendar, and I didn't want to do that. It also doesn't proactively give me hints, so that didn't work.
quote_b: If the AI were connected to my calendar, it would help me plan and think about when might be a good time for things. Of course, I would need to keep everything in my calendar, which I don't do at the moment.
explanation: She declined to share calendar data with AI because she did not want to, yet later describes calendar integration as the key enabler of her ideal assistant — while also admitting she does not maintain her calendar.

quote_a: 3 - Moderate trust
quote_b: For example, if I make some plans, it will automatically mark them in my calendar and send an email or note or message to notify the people involved. It will also remind me when the events are happening in advance.
explanation: A self-reported moderate trust in AI (3/5) sits in tension with a willingness to grant AI full autonomy over calendar entries and outbound communications to other people.

quote_a: My most common use for AI would be in the garden. What I do is use ChatGPT specifically to set up an annual flow of the tasks that I need to do in my garden. I ask what kind of work I can do in winter, what I should be doing in spring, summer, and autumn. I use it to estimate how long that work would take, set times for growth, match the plants I have with companion plants that will grow well together, and help me diagnose issues with my trees.
quote_b: I think it comes down to surface-level issues. AI specifically can't relate to certain things that I'm speaking about, like being forgetful or the gardening topics, where a human would be able to engage more deeply. A human might say, "Oh, has this happened? Have you seen...?" There's just a deeper level of conversation between humans than between a human and an AI.
explanation: The participant describes gardening as their most common AI use case and relies on it heavily for garden planning, yet later claims AI specifically cannot relate to gardening topics — opposing sentiments about AI's utility in the same domain.

quote_a: Basically, I would like it to proactively manage the admin tasks that I would do myself, freeing up my time to focus on more creative work.
quote_b: However, at the moment, I would not allow the AI to autonomously do things because it still makes mistakes.
explanation: The participant expresses a strong desire for AI to autonomously manage admin tasks, then immediately states they would not allow autonomous AI action due to reliability concerns.

quote_a: I think it would need to be connected to those apps in order to autonomously do things on my behalf.
quote_b: Realistically, I probably would not give the AI that much access to my personal data because I would be concerned about the privacy implications of that.
explanation: The participant acknowledges that app connectivity is required for their desired autonomous AI, but then admits they would not grant the data access that this connectivity requires.

quote_a: I mainly use AI for quick corrections and rephrasing sentences for administrative email communications.
quote_b: what would interest me is that it is directly connected, at least in my professional case, directly to our data and that it provides more precision. Because, at present, I give it a lot of context with variables, and it is not capable, at least with us, of retrieving these variables and therefore performing an analysis, for example.
explanation: The participant frames their AI use as mainly limited to email corrections, but then describes actively attempting to use AI for complex data variable retrieval and analysis, revealing a broader and more ambitious engagement than the narrow framing suggests.

quote_a: I don't see a need for it yet, and I don't, yeah, I don't see a need.
quote_b: Maybe for reminding me about things on my calendar or errands I need to run, perhaps anticipating the best way to combine errands in a more efficient manner than I might do on my own, or letting me know about opportunities I might not be on the lookout for.
explanation: The participant claims no perceived need for AI, yet when prompted describes specific, detailed use cases with clear personal utility, revealing latent desire that contradicts the stated indifference.

quote_a: I feel comfortable conducting research on my own without any kind of AI assistance.
explanation: Unprompted assertion of self-sufficiency reads as defensive justification for non-use rather than a neutral description, suggesting the participant may be convincing themselves rather than simply reporting a fact.

quote_a: I admittedly had some reservations about how that would go because I feel like that's one of the integral parts of being interviewed by a human—being able to pick up on certain details that you might add in, along with certain facial expressions or maybe certain tones, and how that can be leveraged to ask a follow-up question and dive deeper into a particular topic or statement.
quote_b: In certain aspects, it was better than I had thought, especially with some of the follow-up questions that seemed to be prompted based on what I had said in the previous question.
explanation: The participant starts with reservations about AI interviews replacing key human elements, then later says the AI interview performed better than expected with effective follow-up questions.

quote_a: I like having conversations with human beings. I enjoy hearing a voice, so not hearing a voice feels kind of impersonal.
quote_b: Sometimes your interviewer doesn't listen as well as an AI might, so that's something to consider.
explanation: The participant says AI interviewing feels impersonal without a human voice, but also says AI can listen better than human interviewers.

quote_a: Being interviewed by an AI is different in that, I think with a human, there’s more relationship, more reciprocity, and more of a conversation. There’s a greater back and forth. With an AI, there’s none of that, so it relies on me to carry the conversation.
quote_b: the AI was able to pick up on things that I had said and ask a follow-up question about that with a specific follow-up rather than just a generic "tell me more about why you gave the answer you did" type of question.
explanation: The participant first claims AI provides no back-and-forth and relies on them to carry the conversation, then contradicts this by crediting the AI for picking up on their answers and asking specific follow-up questions.

quote_a: 3 - Moderate trust
quote_b: I will definitely have to consent to it, but I would prefer if it could actually follow me around for a few days and try to learn what I do. Then it could maybe map out the way I think and how my mind operates.
explanation: The participant reports only moderate trust in AI, yet endorses highly intimate behavioral tracking by a personal assistant that follows daily routines.

quote_a: Once I asked for a knitting pattern, I like to knit and crochet, and I asked it to help me create a sweater pattern. It didn't work very well, but it was useful to get ideas on what colors I could combine.
explanation: The participant admits the AI failed at the requested task but immediately pivots unprompted to a positive framing, softening the failure rather than accepting it at face value.

quote_a: The most common personal tasks I use AI for are really just summarizing information from the web. I'm using Perplexity as a kind of default search engine to skip straight to the synthesis.
quote_b: It's interesting with AI because a little bit of wrong is sometimes just the straw that makes it all not useful.
explanation: The participant presents AI as a default tool for synthesis, then walks this back by saying small errors can make outputs not useful.

quote_a: ChatGPT is likely to give me an answer that's at least 80% accurate, compared to Googling, which results in a bunch of website links that I then have to sift through to find the answer. So, it's quicker if I just ask.
quote_b: accurate information will always be the most important factor ... the most difficult aspect of AI assistance right now is that they are not accurate, and there's also no way to know which parts are not accurate, especially if you're not an expert in the field that we're discussing.
explanation: In Q4 the participant accepts 80% accuracy as sufficient and praises AI speed, but in Q8 frames AI inaccuracy as the primary and most difficult problem, contradicting the earlier positive stance on accuracy.

quote_a: ChatGPT is likely to give me an answer that's at least 80% accurate, compared to Googling, which results in a bunch of website links that I then have to sift through to find the answer. So, it's quicker if I just ask.
quote_b: the question for me is whether it really shortens the time I spend on these tools. Is it really improving them?
explanation: The participant explicitly states AI is quicker than searching in Q4, but in Q9 questions whether AI actually shortens time on tools, undermining the earlier time-saving claim.

quote_a: It should offer me interesting products, events, or courses for further education and new topics. It should be able to assist me in every life situation, especially in health, hobbies, sports, and nutrition.
quote_b: The human is real, the human is authentic. The human can say what is really going on inside them, and a human dialogue is a real dialogue. I can see the person, I can talk to them, I can perceive their tone of voice, their facial expression, their eyes. And above all, if I know them, I know that this person is genuine and not computer-controlled.
explanation: The participant wants AI to assist in every life situation, but then positions the human as categorically authentic and genuine in contrast to being computer-controlled, which undermines the breadth of personal life assistance they expect from AI.

quote_a: My personal AI assistant should know all my life situations, my needs in daily life, my hobbies, my career, my interests, my further and advanced training, as well as my interests in concerts, movies, and cultural matters.
quote_b: I prefer an interview with a human because it is a dialogue and not a monologue. A personal human address cannot be replaced by anything, not even by AI.
explanation: The participant describes an intimate, deeply integrated AI assistant that should know every aspect of their personal life, yet simultaneously insists that personal human address cannot be replaced by anything, not even AI — opposite sentiments about AI’s capacity to fulfil personal needs.

quote_a: This feels more mechanical, not necessarily in a bad way, but it just doesn't feel like a similar type of interaction to me.
quote_b: I think I mirror back the sense of it being mechanical in the way I respond. There's a lack of warmth and a lack of connection, and I believe that affects how I choose to engage.
explanation: He initially qualifies the mechanical feeling as not necessarily bad, but then reveals it does negatively affect his engagement by producing a lack of warmth and connection.

quote_a: What motivates me to build these apps is the fear of being left behind by technology and becoming obsolete.
quote_b: I don't really want it to do any of those things. I prefer to make those decisions directly. I don't trust an AI assistant enough to know what my choice would be in all those situations.
explanation: He states that fear of obsolescence drives him to build apps with AI, yet his revealed preference is to avoid delegating any decisions to AI and maintain direct control, undermining the implied engagement.

quote_a: I think that I would definitely need it to have more agent-like qualities than AI currently has. I know that some of the AI companies have things like ChatGPT has an operator feature. However, it's quite buggy, and you still really need to watch it. You can't really trust it to just go out and do things for you.
explanation: Participant acknowledges the agentic features they desire already exist but immediately frames them as too buggy to use, which reads as a defensive rationalisation for why their ideals for AI are not yet met rather than a straightforward description.

quote_a: 4 - High trust
quote_b: I think that I would definitely need it to have more agent-like qualities than AI currently has. I know that some of the AI companies have things like ChatGPT has an operator feature. However, it's quite buggy, and you still really need to watch it. You can't really trust it to just go out and do things for you.
explanation: Participant rates their trust in AI as 4 (High) but immediately qualifies that agent features are too buggy to trust for autonomous action, directly undermining the stated trust level.

quote_a: I'd say I use AI most often for searching things and finding quick answers. I really like how nuanced you can get with your searches instead of just typing keywords and then searching and going through all the different results that come up.
quote_b: Sometimes I don't use it because I can tell that I'm going to have to give it a lot more context than I could just do in my brain. Like, I'll think it's faster for me to just write out this message or give advice for this thing because I just know more about it.
explanation: Participant describes AI search as their primary and preferred use, but reveals they regularly choose not to use it when tasks require context, suggesting the commitment to AI-first searching is selective rather than habitual.

quote_a: At first, I was like, really? Camera and audio? I feel like a lot of times I don't use AI tools with the camera or audio. I get nervous about it. It almost feels like phone call anxiety, like when you need to call someone. It's like when you're a little kid and, for the first time, you have to call the dentist to make an appointment. For some reason, AI feels like that to me when I'm doing it through video or call.
quote_b: I also liked that I was able to answer in voice to really get my thoughts out quickly and in the way that I'm naturally used to. However, I appreciated that it responds to me through text. For instance, this question here is in text instead of a voice coming back at me, which allows me to look at it and see the entire question. Sometimes there might be a two-part question, and I might forget the second part.
explanation: Participant expresses strong anxiety about using AI with voice or audio, yet within the same session praises the voice input format as natural and pleasant — the contradiction resolves partly through the text-response preference, but the initial anxiety contrasts sharply with the reported enjoyment.
